abstract.p: Letter from Asst Sec David K Garman disputes May 30 editorial accusing Bush administration of rolling back Clinton-era energy efficiency standards for air-conditioners; says new standard is 20 percent increase from pre-Clinton standard

block.p: Your May 30 editorial ''Wrong Way on Energy'' criticized the Bush administration for its decision to ''roll back Clinton-era energy efficiency standards for air-conditioners.'' But the new standard is not a rollback; it's a 20 percent increase from the pre-Clinton standard.

Your May 30 editorial ''Wrong Way on Energy'' criticized the Bush administration for its decision to ''roll back Clinton-era energy efficiency standards for air-conditioners.'' But the new standard is not a rollback; it's a 20 percent increase from the pre-Clinton standard.

Our standard for residential air-conditioners is the same originally proposed by the Clinton administration on Oct. 5, 2000. In its final hours, the Clinton administration ordered a 30 percent increase, but it failed to fully consider the effect on manufacturers and consumers as required under the law.

After we considered all the factors, we found the 20 percent increase justifiable. And we were not alone in this judgment. The Senate, including New York's two senators, voted to strike down the 30 percent higher standard in the energy bill.
DAVID K. GARMAN Asst. Secy., Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Washington, June 3, 2002
